awd_titl_txt: Questions and Experiments in Geometric Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
Polytopes have been studied by mathematicians, scientists, and artists for thousands of years. The modern theory of polytopes connects diverse areas of pure mathematics and is used in applied mathematics as well. Polytopes are used to determine solutions of transportation problems, model possible outcomes of elections, and investigate biological phenomena. The special class of lattice polytopes have deep connections with combinatorial enumeration, which is the precise counting of complicated but finite sets. This award will lead to a deeper understanding of lattice polytopes and their relation to enumeration and counting, using tools primarily from number theory and algebra. In addition to expanding basic research in mathematics, this award will broaden and strengthen the mathematical sciences workforce by supporting the training of graduate students in both pure and experimental approaches to mathematics.

This research is focused on two broad goals: (A) prove theoretical results about combinatorial properties of lattice polytopes and (B) generate and analyze data about lattice polytopes resulting from computational experiments. The first project in this proposal focuses on unimodality problems for Ehrhart h-star-polynomials, with particular emphasis on challenging conjectures due to Stanley, Hibi-Ohsugi, and De Loera-Haws-Koeppe. The study of Ehrhart h-star-unimodality has led to a significant increase in our understanding of lattice polytopes, and focusing on these difficult conjectures will lead to further advances. The second project in this proposal involves a comprehensive study of geometric and algebraic aspects of a family of lattice simplices related to weighted projective spaces. By investigating Hilbert bases, Ehrhart h-star-vectors, Poincare series, and geometric h-star-polynomial factorizations for these lattice simplices, a refined understanding of their properties will emerge that can inform our study of lattice simplices in general. The third project focuses on the class of generalized permutahedra and their relationship to Hopf algebras. The combinatorial enumeration of faces of these polytopes is known to be a subtle and interesting problem, and this project will create an extension of traditional face enumeration to refined face enumeration using symmetric functions and combinatorial Hopf algebras for this class of polytopes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polytopes are geometric objects, such as cubes and tetrahedra, that are foundational to mathematics and applied science. The main focus of this project was polytopes that are defined using mathematical structures that are finite and discrete, such as graphs, partially ordered sets, and decompositions of integers into ordered sums. This project led to new discoveries regarding triangulations of polytopes, computations of their volumes, and the number of points in polytopes that have all integer coordinates.

More specifically, this project supported the study of Ehrhart theory, which is hte study of counting integer points in polytopes, with a strong focus on Gorenstein polytopes. Gorenstein polytopes are special because their Ehrhart polynomials have symmetric coefficients, which represents subtle and complicated algebraic structure. Through this award, the Principle Investigator and his collaborators were able to find new examples of Gorenstein polytopes arising from flows on transportation networks, and to prove unimodality for certain probability distributions arising from Ehrhart theory. The Principle Investigator and his collaborators also investigated geometric properties of Gorenstein lattice polytopes defined by integer partitioned, again determining multiple classes where Ehrhart unimodality holds.

The Principle Investigator mentored five doctoral students funded by this award, all of whom received training in mathematics research and teaching methods. Further, the Principle Investigator conducted this work in collaboration with researchers across the globe.

Beyond the mathematics research that was the main focus of this project, the Principle Investigator also collaborated with mathematics educators and psychologists to develop new tools for assessing undergraduate students' beliefs and belongings in math courses, along with the impact of these beliefs and belongings. Thus, this award supported research in mathematics education, contributing broadly beyond the theory of polytopes that was the award focus.
